audio_caption: The clip begins with someone impatiently urging others to slow down, followed by sounds of knocking and the speaker yelling about senseless violence, demanding cooperation, and then the sound of someone shuffling. A somber, slow string piece follows with a melancholic tone, then the sound of someone sighing. A male voice, sounding weary and somewhat resigned, thanks someone. The clip concludes with the sound of a cigarette being offered and accepted, as the weary voice says "Thank you".

The audio clip features a single male speaker, who sounds sophisticated and slightly wry. He begins by suggesting that if the listener had approached the house normally, they would have been invited to lunch. He goes on to say he has anticipated meeting the listener for years. He then admits he doesn't know the listener. He finishes by saying "like you, my dear Thorndyke".

The audio clip opens with a male speaker discussing his passion for big game hunting, contrasting it with his involvement in politics, which he describes as a more exciting field of action. He mentions recognizing someone named Thorndike from their exploits in Nairobi. Another male speaker then notes that his passport has been taken. The first male speaker then assures Thorndike that he would have recognized him on sight.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker mentioning "a guest in this house" and asking if the listener knows his brother. The speaker then refers to someone sent by the prime minister "on a mission of appeasement" and describes him as a "credulous simpleton". Continuing, he notes that the location is the "most closely guarded house in the world". The tone is serious.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker asserting his belief that nothing could have entered a certain area unseen, then counters his statement by describing an animal skilled in stealth. He elaborates on the open, vulnerable landscape before revealing the presence of a man with a rifle, remarking on his uncanny judgment of distance. Then, the tone shifts towards the idea that this man cannot be allowed to live. Another male voice interrupts, questioning whether the first man thinks he's an assassin. The first man clarifies that he never intended to shoot, but was experimenting to find out if it were possible, emphasizing that the excitement of it, the danger, the fun. He says that someone jumping him made the gun go off, and then states that his companion is disappointed.

The clip begins with a male speaker admitting he may have been "a bit thick", explaining he assumed the other party knew it was a "sporting stalk", clarifying "stalking the game... for the fun of it, not to kill". He questions the other's "claims as a hunter of big game if you failed to understand the fascination" of hunting the biggest game on earth. Another male voice responds that "the most dangerous of all animals" is man, to which the first male voice responds that the "sport is in the chase, not the kill". He specifies he doesn't kill anymore, because the rifle work is "sheer cruelty and I don't like cruelty." He is interested in the instinct of an animal that isn't going to let him near enough to shoot. The second male speaker indicates that the conversation is fascinating, but questions the "softness" of the other's nature when it comes to firearms.

The clip begins with a male speaker accusing someone of weakness and decadence. He says "symbolic of the English race" and accuses others of being "symbolic of yours", then states they "are finding a new life" in "primitive virtues". The speaker continues stating that they "do not hesitate to destroy in order to create a new world" in an arrogant tone. A second speaker reacts with "God help it". Lastly, the clip ends with a dissonant sound, that sounds like a horror movie sound effect.

The clip begins with a man expressing sorrow for another. There's then a transition to a somber, brass-heavy musical piece, reminiscent of a funeral dirge, with prominent use of what sounds like a tuba. The music fades slightly as a man, who sounds somewhat authoritative, says you could leave the country a free man, then asks on what conditions. Another man inquires about the contents of the note, asking if it is a suicide note.

The clip starts with a stern male voice making an accusation, asking if "on this 29th day of July 1939" the individual had attempted to assassinate their FÃ¼hrer and "undertaken this crime with the approval of your government". This is followed by an incredulous male voice questioning the accusation, seemingly in disbelief, asking if the accuser is serious and asserting he would never sign a lie. The first voice presses on, questioning why the accused didn't leave his rifle behind if he truly had no intention to shoot, after which the second, more contemplative male voice responds that "It wouldn't have been sporting". A brief, subtle dramatic musical score is present in the background.

The clip begins with a male speaker criticizing the hypocrisy of the English, referencing the phrase "playing the game," and arguing against playing it to win. He continues, expressing his intent to kill someone to make a point. A second male voice warns the first not to continue with his line of thought. The first speaker retorts with a sarcastic "Oh, no thank you." Music, reminiscent of a thriller film score, plays throughout the final half of the clip. In addition to the music, a train approaches and then moves past.

The audio clip starts with a male voice issuing a demand, "for the last time, will you sign this document," in a stern and authoritative tone. Another male voice responds defiantly, stating, "That's for me to decide, isn't it?" followed by a philosophical reflection. The first speaker then threatens the other with physical harm if he does not cooperate. The sounds of clanking metal underscore the tension and setting the scene. The clip concludes with sounds like a gong, further building suspense.
